comment_data.body: After some investigations, `TERM=xterm-256color nvim` lets me Ctrl-Z properly. I made my putty report the `putty-256color` termcaps by default, which seem sto make Ctrl-Z fail to work.

I can confirm that the following will not background nvim:
- `env TERM=putty-256color nvim -u NONE`
- Hit <kbd>Ctrl-Z</kbd>

However, I believe it is the correct behavior, considering that Ctrl-Z isn’t enabled by default in Putty. Sure, setting `TERM` incorrectly breaks things, but that’s not new.

With putty-256color set, I haven't met a single app that refused to go to background, except for neovim. It's ok since hacking the TERM variable fixes it, but that isn't the expected behavior, regardless of whether it is correct or not (I have long abandoned the idea of correctness when it came to terminal emulation...)

This also happens when TERM=linux

Running nvim in tty2 does this and so does "TERM=linux nvim" from inside xterm and st

In fact this happens with any terminfo which contains kspd

```
infocmp linux | grep kspd
kmous=\E[M, knp=\E[6~, kpp=\E[5~, kspd=^Z, nel=^M^J, oc=\E]R,

infocmp putty-256color | grep kspd
kmous=\E[M, knp=\E[6~, kpp=\E[5~, kri=\EOA, kspd=^Z,
```

However these work

```
infocmp xterm | grep kspd
# no results found

infocmp st | grep kspd
# no results found
```

Not sure of what is exactly causing the issue though

nvim 0.1.1
No response from c-z after c-v in insert mode and command mode.

@akavel Ctrl-Z was not ever supposed to be converted to SIGTSTP, Vim and, after it, Neovim was always supposed to handle keys in order (which is especially relevant given that `<C-z>` meaning depends on mode in which it is used, and this meaning is not necessary “suspend Neovim”), so `<C-z>` is not supposed to be handled up until previous input was handled, which is much easier to do if you are not using signals.

It would be weird if signal handler _was_ called, this is simply unnecessary complication: in this handler you would need to push `<C-z>` into input queue. Keys like `<C-s>`, `<C-z>`, `<C-q>`, `<C-d>` (BTW, this one also does not mean EOF for (Neo)Vim) are easy to disable using `stty`, for `<C-z>` this would be `stty susp ''` (and, of course, everybody is free to use the same method stty is using on its own to avoid spawning a process).
The PR I sent above seems to fix it for me, and still work in xterm.

Environment:

Windows 10
Windows Terminal
Git Bash from "Git For Windows"
Neovim 0.9.5 from GitHub release, not master source.
```
$ env |grep TERM
TERM=xterm-256color
``
CTRL-Z in normal mode does nothing.

Expected behavior:
Drop into the shell, and can resume with shell fg command.

vim from Git 4 Windows works ok

title: Neovim refuses to go to background with Ctrl-Z
